instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Hi,

I have this board which apparently had liquid damage and been cleaned afterwards.
At least now there is nothing visible anymore.
Voltmeter says 20V at 500-650mA.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.2V, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and _S0 rails present.
Also <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> present. 
No USB activity.
CPU gets warm (~50°C without fan), but also <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7220</CHIP> are always a bit warmer (~2-3°C).
What can I check next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Try known good working BIOS.
Did you test USB activity on all ports?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Yes, tried with all 4 ports.

This
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-read-write-erase-apple-efi-spi-rom-with-raspberry-pi.2455/[/URL]
method should work right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I have never touched a Raspberry device.
Medusa is the best and classic USB programmer is probably more easy to use than Raspberry Pi.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I just flashed the SPI ROM. still the same. What can i do next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Do you note any variation at  <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  in the first 10-15s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Then the board doesn't really boot, just stays on.
Where did you get the BIOS file?

Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces (page 59).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
The bios is from badcaps forum, described as 100% working.
I checked the resistors and traces (except to the cpu pads) and all seems well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Any advice what to do next?
Do <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/7220 get that hot on a good board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Liquid spill near the CPU could be letal...
